Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 08:52AM ladybugcyndi wrote: My 5 boosts were very quick, did like 15 seconds on each side angled at the lumpectomy site and I was done.  My underarm was raw at this point, so the break was a welcome thing.
Posts.Title: boosts?? zschweeb zschweeb

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2008 11:06AM ladybugcyndi wrote: I just finished my final taxotere/cytoxan treatment a week ago today.  With each treatment I felt very good for the first 48 hours.  At about 48 hours out, I started with bone pain in my lower back, hips and thighs.  It lasted for about 48 hours and was done.  It was not unbearable, but uncomfortable, and aleve worked fine for it, nothing stronger was needed for me.  I did get the neuropathy that everyone is talking about though.  With the first treatment, it was very painful, started about 5 days out and was in both feet and hands.  I started on vitamin B-6 as directed by my doctor and it did help.  With taxotore, be prepared for the possible "itching" side effect.  My hands itched for about a week, starting at day 3 or 4, very badly.  I picked up a lotion called Carmyl 10, over the counter at the pharmacy, as directed by doctor and used it.  No amount of cortisone or other over the counter lotions will help, believe me, I tried them all.  With each treatment, I got both the itching and the neuropathy.  I stayed on the B-6 the entire time and am still on it.  With the last one, my neuropathy in my feet has been worse, its rather painful at this point.  My fingers are very sensitive for about a week, so I am nearing that time frame with this one.  With the first one, be very aware and prepared for the lack of taste buds at about day 4 or 5.  That was a surprise to me, and the reason I ended up in the hospital.  I quit drinking cause everything tasted horrible to me, got dehydrated and landed for an over night stay at the hospital.  It only happened once, and will not happen again.  You have to make a conscience effort to drink plenty of fluids, no matter how much you don't want too.  I was on zofram and decadron, with compozine as a back up and had absolutely no nausea throughout it all.  Also, constipation, be prepared for that too.  Zofram (for nausea) and most chemo drugs will cause it, so start on fiber or something in advance.  Discuss it with your doctor and see what they recommend.  Mine recommended trying senekot, which did help.  There are a ton of tips and tricks .. but most of all, allow yourself to find what works best for you.  Don't work yourself up prior to treatment, you'll find like most of us did, that the first one is very anti-climatic.  I expected something, anything, but it was just a treatment.  I didn't feel anything differently for 2 days.
